landing.title: Kidney Treatment Decision Aid
landing.subtitle: NHS Renal Services
landing.description: This tool will help you understand your kidney treatment options and think about what matters most to you. Take your time - there are no right or wrong answers.
landing.startButtonAriaLabel: Start your kidney treatment decision journey
landing.featuresSubheading: Everything you need to make an informed decision about your kidney treatment

time.title: Takes About 15 Minutes
time.description: Complete at your own pace. You can take breaks whenever you need and return to where you left off.

privacy.title: Your Privacy Protected
privacy.description: No personal information is stored. Your answers help personalise the tool during this session only.

devices.title: Works on All Devices
devices.description: Use on your phone, tablet, or computer. The tool adapts to your screen size automatically.

about.paragraph1: This decision aid will help you explore the different treatment options available for kidney failure. You can learn about each treatment at your own pace, think about what matters most to you, and create a summary to share with your doctor or nurse.
about.paragraph2: You will answer a few simple questions about your situation, then explore treatments that may be suitable for you. Your information stays private and is not saved after you close the browser.
about.paragraph3: This tool does not replace medical advice from your healthcare team. It is designed to help you feel more informed and confident when discussing your options. Your kidney team are the experts in your care and will help you make the right decision for you.

landing.ctaDescription: Take the first step towards understanding your kidney treatment options. You can start now and come back later if you need a break.

language.title: Choose Your Language
language.instruction: Please select your preferred language. You can change this at any time.
language.confirmChangeMessage: Are you sure you want to change the language to {{language}}? All text will be updated.

privacy.title: Your Privacy & Information
privacy.subtitle: Before you begin, we want you to understand how this tool handles your information.

privacy.title: How We Protect Your Information
privacy.content: Your responses are processed securely and are not stored permanently. This tool does not collect personal health information that can identify you. Your session data is automatically deleted when you close this tool.
privacy.p1: This tool uses session-only storage. Any information you enter, including your answers to questions and treatment preferences, is only kept while you are using the tool.
privacy.p2: When you close your browser or after 15 minutes of inactivity, all your information is automatically deleted. We do not save anything about you.
privacy.p3: We collect anonymous information about how people use this tool to help us improve it. This cannot identify you personally.

ai.title: How This Tool Works
ai.content: This decision aid uses technology to provide personalised information based on your responses. The information provided is drawn from NHS clinical guidelines and evidence-based research. This tool supports but does not replace discussions with your kidney care team.
ai.p1: This tool includes an AI assistant that can answer general questions about kidney treatments. The AI provides information only - it cannot give you medical advice specific to your situation.
ai.p2: The AI may sometimes make mistakes or provide incomplete information. Always discuss important decisions with your kidney team who know your full medical history.
ai.p3: This tool does not replace advice from your healthcare team. It is designed to help you feel more informed when discussing your options with your doctors and nurses.

medical.title: Important Medical Information
medical.content: This tool provides general information about kidney treatment options. It is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always consult with your kidney specialist or healthcare team before making any decisions about your treatment. If you have urgent health concerns, please contact your GP or call NHS 111.

pii.title: Please Do Not Share Personal Details
pii.intro: To protect your privacy, please do not enter any personal information that could identify you when using this tool, especially in the chat feature.
pii.outro: You can still tell us about your situation in general terms - for example, your living situation or what matters most to you - without sharing identifying details.

summary.title: In Summary
summary.leave: You can leave at any time

consent.title: Please confirm to continue
consent.understand: I understand that my information is not saved after this session and I will not share personal identifying information
consent.analytics: I agree to anonymous analytics being collected to help improve this tool (optional)
consent.error: Please confirm you understand the privacy information before continuing

privacy.readFullPolicy: Read the full NHS Privacy Policy

header.homeAriaLabel: NHS Kidney Treatment Decision Aid - Home

journey.title: Where Are You in Your Kidney Care Journey?
journey.subtitle: Select the option that best describes your situation
journey.instruction: Select the option that best describes your current situation
journey.intro: Everyone's kidney journey is different. To help us show you the most relevant information, please tell us where you are right now. There are no right or wrong answers.
journey.error: Please select an option that describes your situation. If none of these fit, select "I am supporting a family member or friend" to continue.
journey.legendLabel: Select where you are in your kidney journey
journey.audioText: Where are you in your journey? Select the option that best describes your situation.
journey.reassurance: Do not worry if you are unsure which option fits best. You can always explore all treatment options later, and your kidney team can help clarify your situation. Your selection helps us show you the most relevant information first.

suspected.title: I think I may have kidney disease
suspected.description: You are concerned about your kidney health and want to learn more about what kidney disease means.

earlyDiagnosis.title: I've just been diagnosed - early stage CKD
earlyDiagnosis.description: You have recently learned about your kidney condition and want to understand what this means for you.

lateDiagnosis.title: I've been diagnosed - late stage CKD
lateDiagnosis.description: Your kidney function has declined significantly and you may need to think about treatment options soon.

choosingTreatment.title: I need to choose a treatment soon
choosingTreatment.description: Your kidney team has told you that you will need to start treatment in the coming months and you want to learn about your options.

transplantPending.title: I'm due to have a transplant - want to learn more
transplantPending.description: You are on the transplant list or have a living donor lined up and want to know more about what to expect.

dialysisPending.title: I'm due to start dialysis - want to learn more
dialysisPending.description: You will be starting dialysis treatment soon and want to understand the different types and what daily life will be like.

supporting.title: I'm supporting a family member or friend
supporting.description: Someone close to you has kidney disease and you want to understand their options to help support them.

helpModal.title: Need Help Choosing?
helpModal.intro: It is perfectly normal to feel unsure about which stage describes you best. Here are some tips:
helpModal.tip1Title: Think about your most recent appointment
helpModal.tip1Text: What did your kidney team tell you about your kidney function and any next steps?
helpModal.tip2Text: Were you given this tool by a doctor or nurse? They may have suggested which stage applies to you.
helpModal.tip3Text: Choose the option that feels closest to your situation. You will still be able to explore all the information in this tool, regardless of which option you select.
helpModal.note: Your kidney team are the experts in your care. If you have questions about your kidney health, please contact them directly.

intro.title: Tell Us About Yourself
intro.description: These questions help us show you information that is most relevant to your situation. Your answers are private and will not be saved after this session.
intro.skipText: If you prefer not to answer these questions, you can skip to general treatment information.

knowledge.title: How much do you know about kidney disease and its treatments?
knowledge.hint: This helps us tailor information to your current understanding.

goal.title: What would you like to get from this session?
goal.hint: Select the option that best describes your main goal today.

learning.title: How do you prefer to learn new information?
learning.hint: This helps us present information in ways that work best for you.

comfort.title: How comfortable are you with medical procedures?
comfort.hint: This is a sensitive topic. You can skip this question if you prefer.

support.title: Do you have support at home?
support.hint: Some treatments are easier with help from family or carers.

living.title: Where do you live?
living.hint: This helps us understand which treatments might work best in your home environment.

priorities.title: What matters most to you in choosing a treatment?
priorities.hint: Your priorities will help us highlight what matters to you in each treatment option.

hints.selectUpTo: Select up to {{max}} priorities that are most important to you.
hints.selectAll: Select all that apply - you can choose more than one option.

learnBasics.label: Learn the basics
learnBasics.description: I want to understand what kidney disease means and the treatment options available

compare.label: Compare my options
compare.description: I already know the basics and want to compare different treatments

prepare.label: Prepare for a discussion
prepare.description: I want to prepare questions and thoughts for my next appointment

support.label: Support someone else
support.description: I am helping a family member or friend understand their options

notSure.label: I am not sure yet
notSure.description: I just want to explore and see what information is available

visual.label: Visual diagrams and images
visual.description: Pictures, charts and diagrams help me understand

audio.label: Listening to information
audio.description: I prefer to hear information read aloud

reading.label: Reading text
reading.description: I like to read detailed written information

video.label: Watching videos
video.description: Videos and animations work best for me

interactive.label: Interactive tools
interactive.description: I learn by doing and exploring

options.familyPartner: Yes, I live with family or a partner who can help
options.carers: Yes, I have professional carers who help me
options.familyNearby: Yes, family live nearby and can visit

options.quality: Quality of life day to day

hub.title: Your Personalised Information
hub.subtitle: Based on your responses, here's what we recommend exploring.

welcome.title: Your Personalised Treatment Options
welcome.message: Based on what you have told us, here are resources to help you understand your kidney condition and explore your options.
welcome.reminder: Remember, your kidney team will help you make the final decision.

alert.title: Remember to save your summary
alert.message: Your information will not be saved after this session. Create a summary before you leave to keep a record of your exploration.

pathway.title: How would you like to explore?

guided.title: Your Recommended Journey
guided.description: Follow a guided step-by-step path through treatment options tailored to your situation. Perfect if you want clear direction and support.

free.title: Explore Freely
free.description: Browse all options at your own pace. Jump directly to topics that interest you. Ideal if you already know what you are looking for.

content.title: Tools to Help You Decide
content.subtitle: Explore each tool to make an informed decision

treatments.title: Treatment Options
treatments.description: Learn about all available kidney treatment options including dialysis types, transplant, and conservative care.

model.title: 3D Kidney Model
model.description: Explore interactive 3D models showing how different treatments work in your body. See the process visually.

compare.title: Compare Treatments
compare.description: See all treatments side by side. Compare what matters to you - from daily time to travel flexibility.

values.title: Values Exercise
values.description: Think about what matters most to you. This exercise helps clarify your priorities to guide your decision.

chat.title: Ask Questions
chat.description: Chat with our AI assistant about kidney treatment options. Get answers to your questions in a conversational way.

lifeGoals.title: Life Goals Compatibility
lifeGoals.description: See how treatments align with your personal goals for work, family, travel, and more.

statistics.title: What Others Chose
statistics.description: See what people in similar situations decided and their outcomes.

summary.title: Ready to Review Your Journey?
summary.description: View everything you have explored and create a summary to share with your kidney team at your next appointment.

treatments.title: Understanding Your Treatment Options
treatments.subtitle: There are different ways to treat kidney failure. Each has benefits and considerations.

conservative.comfort: Focus on comfort and quality of life

transplant.title: Kidney Transplant
transplant.shortDescription: A new healthy kidney from a donor
transplant.description: Someone gives you one of their kidneys to replace your own. This could be a family member, friend, or someone who has died and wanted to help. The new kidney does the cleaning job your kidneys cannot do anymore. You take daily tablets to help your body accept it.
transplant.simpleExplanation: Think of it like getting a new kidney to replace ones that no longer work. After the operation, most days feel normal - the main difference is remembering to take your tablets.
benefits: Feel more like yourself - most people say it gives the best quality of life
No dialysis sessions - no hours spent at hospital or on machines
Eat and drink more freely - fewer food rules to follow
More energy - many people feel more awake and able to do things
considerations: Need an operation - about 3 hours of surgery with recovery time
Take tablets every day for life - to stop your body fighting the new kidney
May need to wait - depends on finding the right kidney for you
Not right for everyone - your doctors will check if it suits your health

hemodialysis.title: Haemodialysis
hemodialysis.shortDescription: A machine cleans your blood at a hospital
hemodialysis.description: A machine cleans your blood for you at a hospital or clinic. It does the job your kidneys cannot do anymore. You visit three times a week, sit in a comfortable chair for 4-5 hours, and trained nurses look after you.
hemodialysis.simpleExplanation: Your blood goes through tubes to the machine, gets cleaned, and comes back to you. Nurses do everything for you - you can read, watch TV, or rest during treatment.
benefits: Nurses do it all for you - no need to learn procedures yourself
Cleans your blood well - powerful machines work thoroughly
Meet other patients - many people enjoy the social side
Nothing to set up at home - no equipment or storage needed
considerations: Three half-days at hospital each week - plus travel time
Need a connection point in your arm - a small operation creates this
May feel tired afterwards - especially at first
Watch what you eat and drink - some limits on food and fluids

peritonealDialysis.title: Peritoneal Dialysis
peritonealDialysis.shortDescription: Home treatment using your own body
peritonealDialysis.description: You clean your blood at home using your own body. A thin tube in your tummy lets special fluid flow in. The fluid soaks up waste from your blood, then you drain it away. You can do this during the day or at night while you sleep.
peritonealDialysis.simpleExplanation: A soft tube goes into your tummy. You fill up with clean fluid, wait while it works, then drain it out. Like rinsing a dirty sponge - the fluid picks up the waste.
benefits: Do it at home - no hospital visits for dialysis
You choose when - fit treatment around your life
No needles - unlike the other type of dialysis
Easier to travel - supplies can be sent to where you are going
considerations: Daily commitment - needs doing every day
Tube in your tummy - stays there all the time
Keep everything clean - to avoid infection
Need space at home - for storing supplies

conservative.title: Conservative Management
conservative.description: Your doctors and nurses help you feel as well as possible using medicines and support, without dialysis. You stay comfortable at home without the time demands of dialysis. This is a valid choice, especially for people who are older or have other health problems.
conservative.simpleExplanation: This is active care focused on keeping you comfortable. Regular check-ups but no dialysis machines or hospital stays. You focus on what matters most to you - comfort, family time, and quality of life.
benefits: Focus on feeling well - aim is quality of life, not just length
No dialysis sessions - your time is your own
Stay at home - in familiar surroundings with loved ones
Keep your routine - as much as possible
considerations: Kidneys will get worse - this cannot be stopped
Symptoms will change - medicines help manage these
Honest conversations needed - about what to expect
Plan ahead - think about your wishes for the future

comparison.title: Compare Treatment Options
comparison.subtitle: See how different treatments compare across key factors.

compare.title: Compare Treatment Options
compare.subtitle: See how different treatments compare across the factors that matter to you.
compare.intro: This comparison shows how each treatment option performs across different aspects of daily life and medical care.
compare.description: This tool helps you compare kidney treatment options side by side. You can focus on the things that matter most to you. Select the factors you want to compare below.
compare.highlightHint: Based on your values and priorities from the questionnaire
compare.scrollHint: Scroll horizontally to see all treatments
compare.guidance: No treatment is perfect for everyone. The best choice depends on your personal situation, health, and values. This comparison is a starting point for discussions with your kidney team.

tooltips.timeCommitment: Consider how much time you can dedicate to treatment each week, including travel and recovery time.
tooltips.location: Think about where you would prefer to receive treatment - at home, in hospital, or a clinic.
tooltips.travel: Consider how important it is to you to be able to travel for holidays or to visit family.
tooltips.diet: Some treatments require stricter dietary restrictions than others.
tooltips.surgery: Consider your comfort level with surgical procedures.
tooltips.supportNeeded: Think about the support available to you from family, carers, or healthcare professionals.
tooltips.scheduleFlexibility: Some treatments offer more flexibility in when and where you can have them.
tooltips.trainingRequired: Some treatments require you to learn new skills before starting.
tooltips.survivalRates: Life expectancy varies by treatment and individual health factors.
tooltips.qualityOfLife: Consider how treatment might affect your day-to-day activities and wellbeing.
tooltips.energyLevels: Different treatments can affect your energy levels in different ways.

compare.filterByValues: Filter the comparison by what matters most to you. Select categories to highlight relevant criteria.
compare.completeValuesPrompt: Complete the values exercise to see personalized recommendations.
compare.insightMessage: Based on your values, {{treatment}} appears to be the best match for what matters most to you. However, the best choice depends on your individual health situation - discuss this with your kidney team.

chat.title: Ask Questions
chat.subtitle: Our AI assistant can answer general questions about kidney treatments.
chat.disclaimer: This assistant provides general information only and is not a substitute for medical advice from your kidney care team.
chat.welcomeMessage: Hello! I'm here to help answer your questions about kidney disease and treatment options. How can I help you today?
chat.errorMessage: Sorry, I couldn't process your message. Please try again.
chat.piiWarning: Please do not share personal information like your name, NHS number, or address. This chat is not saved.

welcome.greeting: Hello! I am the NHS Kidney Care Assistant. I am here to help you understand kidney treatment options.
welcome.prompt: You can ask me questions about dialysis, transplants, conservative care, or anything else related to kidney treatment. How can I help you today?

questions.q1: What is the difference between haemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis?
questions.q2: How long does a kidney transplant surgery take?
questions.q3: Can I travel while on dialysis?
questions.q4: What are the side effects of dialysis treatment?
questions.q5: How do I know if I am suitable for a transplant?
questions.q6: What is conservative care and who might choose it?

quickReplies.prosAndCons: What are the pros and cons?
quickReplies.dailyLife: How does this affect daily life?

values.title: What Matters to You
values.subtitle: Rate how important each factor is to you. This helps us personalise your information.
values.instructions: Move the slider to indicate importance (1 = Not important, 5 = Very important)

intro.title: What Matters Most to You?
intro.description: Choosing a kidney treatment is a personal decision. This exercise helps you think about your values and priorities so you can discuss them with your kidney team.
intro.whyMattersText: Every kidney treatment has different effects on your daily life. Understanding what matters most to you helps identify which treatment options might suit you best.
intro.benefit1: See how each treatment aligns with your priorities
intro.benefit2: Prepare for conversations with your kidney team
intro.benefit3: Feel more confident in your decision-making
intro.allAtOnce: Prefer to see all statements at once?

values.defaultHint: Rate how important this is to you from 1 (Not important) to 5 (Very important)

allAtOnce.title: Rate All Statements
allAtOnce.description: Rate each statement from 1 (Not important) to 5 (Very important).

results.title: Your Values Profile
results.description: Based on your responses, here is what matters most to you and how treatments align with your values.
results.viewTreatments: View treatments that match your values
results.treatmentAlignmentDesc: Based on your priorities, here is how each treatment aligns with what matters to you.
results.alignmentDisclaimer: This is a guide based on your stated preferences, not a medical recommendation. Your kidney team will help you find the best treatment for your specific situation.
results.noPriorities: No values were rated as "Important" or "Very important". You can edit your ratings to see your top priorities.
results.nextSteps: What Would You Like to Do Next?

travel.text: Being able to travel and go on holiday is important to me
travel.hint: Think about trips, visiting family, or holidays abroad
travel.example: Going abroad for holidays, visiting family in other cities

hospitalTime.text: I want to minimise time spent at hospital or clinic
hospitalTime.hint: Consider how often you want to travel to medical appointments
hospitalTime.example: Fewer trips to hospital, more time at home

needles.text: I am comfortable with needles and medical procedures
needles.hint: Some treatments involve regular needles or procedures
needles.example: Having blood taken, needle insertions for dialysis

independence.text: Maintaining my independence and managing my own care is very important
independence.hint: Being in control of your treatment and daily life
independence.example: Doing treatment yourself, making your own schedule

familyBurden.text: I want to minimise the impact on my family and carers
familyBurden.hint: Consider how treatment affects those who support you
familyBurden.example: Not needing family to drive you to appointments

longevity.text: Living as long as possible is my priority
longevity.hint: Some treatments have better long-term survival outcomes
longevity.example: Maximising life expectancy is most important to me

qualityOfLife.text: Day-to-day quality of life matters more than length of life
qualityOfLife.hint: Prioritising how you feel each day over total years
qualityOfLife.example: Feeling well daily is more important than living longer

homeTreatment.text: I would prefer to have my treatment at home
homeTreatment.example: Doing dialysis at home instead of a hospital

workActivities.text: Continuing to work or do my usual activities is important
workActivities.hint: Some treatments fit better with work schedules
workActivities.example: Being able to work, exercise, or pursue hobbies

professionalCare.text: I would rather have healthcare professionals manage my treatment
professionalCare.hint: Having trained staff handle your care
professionalCare.example: Nurses doing your dialysis at a centre

independence.text: Maintaining my independence and being able to care for myself
independence.hint: Being able to do daily activities without relying heavily on others

schedule.text: Having flexibility in my schedule and being able to travel
schedule.hint: Being able to plan activities and trips without strict treatment times

hospitalTime.text: Spending less time at hospital or clinic
hospitalTime.hint: Minimising the number and length of hospital visits

homeComfort.text: Receiving treatment in the comfort of my home
homeComfort.hint: Being able to manage treatment at home rather than a medical facility

familyBurden.text: Not being a burden on my family
familyBurden.hint: Minimising the impact of my treatment on family members and carers

longevity.hint: Prioritising treatments that may extend life expectancy

qualityOfLife.text: Quality of life over length of life
qualityOfLife.hint: Prioritising daily wellbeing and comfort over maximum lifespan

energyLevels.text: Having good energy levels and feeling well
energyLevels.hint: Minimising fatigue and maintaining normal energy for activities

dietRestrictions.text: Having fewer restrictions on food and drink
dietRestrictions.hint: Being able to eat and drink with minimal limitations

naturalApproach.text: Taking a more natural approach with fewer interventions
naturalApproach.hint: Preferring treatment options that feel less invasive or medical

modelViewer.title: 3D Kidney Model Viewer
modelViewer.interactiveDescription: Explore an interactive 3D model of human kidneys. Use your mouse or touch to rotate and zoom.
modelViewer.kidneyInfo: Your kidneys are bean-shaped organs about the size of your fist. They filter about 200 litres of blood daily, removing waste and extra fluid.
modelViewer.functionInfo: Kidneys regulate blood pressure, produce hormones, balance body fluids, and filter waste products into urine.
modelViewer.failureInfo: When kidneys lose function, treatments like dialysis or transplant can help do the work your kidneys can no longer do.
modelViewer.continueJourney: Continue your journey by exploring treatment options

kidney.label: Kidney
kidney.description: The main filtering organ that removes waste from your blood and produces urine.

renalArtery.label: Renal Artery
renalArtery.description: Carries blood from the heart to the kidney for filtering.

renalVein.label: Renal Vein
renalVein.description: Carries filtered blood from the kidney back to the heart.

ureter.label: Ureter
ureter.description: The tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder.

adrenalGland.label: Adrenal Gland
adrenalGland.description: A small gland on top of the kidney that produces important hormones.

summary.title: Your Session Summary
summary.subtitle: Here's a summary of what you've explored today.

statistics.description: You reviewed statistics about what other patients in similar situations chose. This information can provide helpful context for your decision.
statistics.disclaimer: Statistics are based on anonymised NHS data and are shown for informational purposes only. Every person is different and your kidney team will help you make the best decision for your individual circumstances.

privacy.title: Your Privacy

disclaimer.title: Important Reminder
disclaimer.text: This summary is for information purposes only and does not constitute medical advice. Always discuss your treatment options with your kidney care team who know your individual circumstances.

timeline.title: A Day in the Life
timeline.subtitle: See what a typical day looks like with this treatment

hemo.rest: Rest and recovery - may feel tired

pd.work: Work or activities - free during day

encouragement.start: Start your journey by exploring treatment options
encouragement.beginning: Great start! Keep exploring to learn more
encouragement.halfway: More than halfway there - well done!
encouragement.almost: Almost complete! Just a few more sections

scenario.title: What If? Scenario Explorer
scenario.subtitle: See how different life situations work with each treatment option

travel.title: What if I want to travel?
travel.description: Explore how each treatment affects your ability to travel for holidays or visits
travel.transplant: After recovery, you can travel freely. Take medications with you and know where to seek care if needed.
travel.transplantTip1: Carry a letter from your transplant team
travel.transplantTip2: Research medical facilities at your destination
travel.transplantTip3: Pack extra medication in hand luggage
travel.hemodialysis: Travel requires advance planning to arrange dialysis at your destination. Holiday dialysis units exist but availability varies.
travel.hemodialysisTip2: Your dialysis team can help with arrangements
travel.hemodialysisTip3: UK travel is easier than international
travel.peritoneal: More freedom to travel. Supplies can be delivered to your destination or you can take them with you.
travel.peritonealTip2: Airlines usually allow extra luggage for supplies
travel.peritonealTip3: Need a clean space for exchanges
travel.conservative: No dialysis restrictions, but travel depends on how you feel. Short trips may be easier to manage.
travel.conservativeTip1: Discuss travel plans with your care team
travel.conservativeTip3: Plan for rest periods during trips

work.title: What if I want to work full-time?
work.description: See how different treatments fit with maintaining employment
work.transplant: After 2-3 months recovery, most people can return to full-time work with near-normal energy levels.
work.transplantTip1: Plan a phased return to work
work.transplantTip2: You may need time off for clinic appointments
work.hemodialysis: Possible but challenging. Sessions take 4-5 hours three times weekly, plus recovery time. Evening/early shifts may help.
work.hemodialysisTip2: Evening or early morning dialysis slots
work.peritoneal: APD overnight means days are free for work. CAPD requires breaks for exchanges but many continue working.
work.peritonealTip1: APD is ideal for full-time workers
work.peritonealTip2: You can do CAPD exchanges at work
work.peritonealTip3: Energy levels often better than HD
work.conservative: Depends on symptoms and energy. Many continue part-time or reduced hours. Focus is on quality of life.

liveAlone.title: What if I live alone?
liveAlone.description: Understand which treatments work well for people living independently
liveAlone.transplant: You will need support during recovery (2-4 weeks), but afterwards can live independently.
liveAlone.transplantTip1: Arrange help for first few weeks post-surgery
liveAlone.hemodialysis: Treatment is done at a centre with professional staff. No home setup required. Regular contact with healthcare team.
liveAlone.peritoneal: Many people do PD alone successfully. Training prepares you well. 24/7 phone support available.
liveAlone.peritonealTip2: Regular home visits from PD nurses
liveAlone.conservative: Initially manageable alone. As symptoms progress, you may need increasing support. Community services can help.
liveAlone.conservativeTip3: Plan ahead for future care needs

family.title: What if I have young children?
family.description: Consider how treatments affect caring for children and family time
family.transplant: After recovery, you can be fully involved in family life. Best quality of life for active parenting.
family.transplantTip2: Can return to normal parenting activities
family.hemodialysis: Regular time away from home for treatment. Tiredness after sessions may affect family activities. Childcare needed during sessions.
family.hemodialysisTip3: Plan family time on non-dialysis days
family.peritoneal: Home-based treatment means more time with family. APD overnight leaves days free for childcare.
family.peritonealTip2: Days are free for school runs
family.conservative: No treatment schedule, but energy levels vary. Focus on quality time with family.
family.conservativeTip2: Accept help with childcare when needed

treatment.quickDaySummary: What a Typical Day Looks Like
treatment.faqDesc: Questions that patients often ask about this treatment
treatment.storiesIntro: These are experiences from real patients. Everyone's journey is different.
treatment.readyDescription: Compare this treatment with others or ask questions to help with your decision.

glossary.title: Medical Terms Glossary
glossary.subtitle: Simple, plain-language definitions of medical terms related to kidney disease and treatment. Use the search box or filter by category to find what you need.

noResults.title: No terms found
noResults.message: Try adjusting your search or filter to find what you are looking for.

help.title: Need more help understanding?
help.description: If you cannot find a term or need more explanation, our AI assistant can help answer your questions about kidney disease and treatments.

dialysis.title: Dialysis
dialysis.definition: A treatment that does some of the work your kidneys can no longer do. It removes waste products, excess salt and water from your blood. There are two main types: haemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis.

haemodialysis.title: Haemodialysis (HD)
haemodialysis.definition: A type of dialysis that uses a machine to filter your blood outside your body. Blood is taken from your body through tubes to a dialysis machine, which filters out waste and extra fluid, then returns the clean blood to your body. Usually done 3 times a week for about 4 hours each session.

peritonealDialysis.title: Peritoneal Dialysis (PD)
peritonealDialysis.definition: A type of dialysis that uses the lining of your tummy (abdomen), called the peritoneum, as a natural filter. A special fluid is put into your tummy through a soft tube, where it absorbs waste products and extra fluid, then is drained out. Can be done at home.

apd.title: APD (Automated Peritoneal Dialysis)
apd.definition: A type of peritoneal dialysis where a machine does the exchanges automatically, usually while you sleep at night. The machine fills and drains the dialysis fluid from your tummy several times during the night, leaving your days free.

capd.title: CAPD (Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis)
capd.definition: A type of peritoneal dialysis where you manually change the fluid in your tummy yourself, usually 3-4 times during the day. Each exchange takes about 30-40 minutes. You can do this at home, work, or while travelling.

dialysate.title: Dialysate
dialysate.definition: The special fluid used in dialysis to help remove waste products and excess water from your blood. In peritoneal dialysis, it is the fluid that goes into your tummy. The fluid attracts waste and extra water from your blood through the peritoneum.

dialysisAdequacy.title: Dialysis Adequacy
dialysisAdequacy.definition: A measure of how well your dialysis treatment is working. Your kidney team regularly checks this through blood tests to make sure you are getting enough dialysis to keep you well.

transplant.title: Kidney Transplant
transplant.definition: An operation to place a healthy kidney from a donor into your body. The new kidney takes over the job of filtering your blood. A successful transplant means you no longer need dialysis, though you will need to take medicines for life to prevent your body rejecting the new kidney.

livingDonor.title: Living Donor
livingDonor.definition: A person who is alive and donates one of their kidneys to someone who needs a transplant. Living donors are often family members or close friends, but can also be people who want to help someone they do not know (altruistic donors). People can live healthy lives with just one kidney.

deceasedDonor.title: Deceased Donor
deceasedDonor.definition: A kidney that comes from someone who has died and agreed to donate their organs, or whose family agreed on their behalf. Most people who receive a kidney transplant get one from a deceased donor.

immunosuppressants.title: Immunosuppressants
immunosuppressants.definition: Medicines that reduce the activity of your immune system. After a kidney transplant, you need to take these medicines for life to stop your body from attacking and rejecting the new kidney. They can make you more likely to get infections.

rejection.title: Rejection
rejection.definition: When your body's immune system recognises the transplanted kidney as foreign and tries to attack it. This is why you need to take immunosuppressant medicines after a transplant. Signs can include feeling unwell, fever, or less urine output.

tissueTyping.title: Tissue Typing
tissueTyping.definition: A blood test that looks at markers on your cells to help find a kidney that is a good match for you. The closer the match between you and the donor, the better the chances of a successful transplant.

waitingList.title: Transplant Waiting List
waitingList.definition: The national list of people waiting for a kidney transplant from a deceased donor. When a suitable kidney becomes available, it is matched to someone on the list based on blood type, tissue type, and other factors.

kidneyFunction.title: Kidney Function
kidneyFunction.definition: How well your kidneys are working. Your kidneys filter waste and extra water from your blood, help control blood pressure, make hormones, and keep your bones healthy. Kidney function is measured through blood and urine tests.

egfr.title: eGFR (Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate)
egfr.definition: A measure of how well your kidneys are filtering waste from your blood. It is calculated from a blood test that measures creatinine. A normal eGFR is above 90. Below 15 usually means kidney failure and the need for treatment like dialysis or transplant.

creatinine.title: Creatinine
creatinine.definition: A waste product made by your muscles that is normally filtered out by your kidneys. A blood test measures how much creatinine is in your blood. High levels can be a sign that your kidneys are not working as well as they should.

ckd.title: CKD (Chronic Kidney Disease)
ckd.definition: A long-term condition where your kidneys do not work as well as they should. CKD is divided into stages 1-5 based on how well your kidneys are working, with stage 5 being the most severe (kidney failure). Many people with CKD can live normal lives with treatment.

kidneyFailure.title: Kidney Failure
kidneyFailure.definition: When your kidneys can no longer work well enough on their own to keep you healthy. Also called end-stage kidney disease or stage 5 CKD. At this stage, you need treatment such as dialysis or a kidney transplant to survive.

uraemia.title: Uraemia
uraemia.definition: A build-up of waste products in your blood that happens when your kidneys cannot filter properly. Symptoms can include feeling tired, sick, itchy skin, poor appetite, and difficulty concentrating. Dialysis or transplant can help remove these waste products.

fistula.title: Fistula (AV Fistula)
fistula.definition: A type of access for haemodialysis created by a small operation that joins an artery to a vein, usually in your arm. This makes the vein bigger and stronger so it can be used for dialysis. A fistula is considered the best type of access for haemodialysis.

graft.title: Graft (AV Graft)
graft.definition: A type of access for haemodialysis where a soft plastic tube is used to connect an artery to a vein, usually in your arm. This is used when your own veins are not suitable for a fistula.

catheter.title: Catheter (Dialysis Line)
catheter.definition: A soft tube that is inserted into a large vein, usually in your neck or chest, to allow access for haemodialysis. A catheter can be used straight away but has a higher risk of infection than a fistula or graft.

pdCatheter.title: PD Catheter (Tenckhoff Catheter)
pdCatheter.definition: A soft, flexible tube that is placed in your tummy during a small operation. It is used to put the dialysis fluid in and drain it out during peritoneal dialysis. The tube stays in place and usually comes out just below your belly button.

vascularAccess.title: Vascular Access
vascularAccess.definition: The way of getting blood out of your body and back in for haemodialysis. This can be through a fistula, graft, or dialysis catheter. Good vascular access is important for effective haemodialysis treatment.

conservativeCare.title: Conservative Care
conservativeCare.definition: A treatment approach that focuses on managing symptoms and maintaining quality of life without dialysis or transplant. It involves medicines, diet changes, and support from your kidney team. Some people choose this option, particularly those who are elderly or have other serious health conditions.

supportiveCare.title: Supportive Care
supportiveCare.definition: Care that helps you live as well as possible with your kidney condition. It includes managing symptoms like pain, tiredness, and sickness, as well as emotional and practical support for you and your family. Supportive care can be given alongside other treatments.

palliativeCare.title: Palliative Care
palliativeCare.definition: Specialist care focused on comfort and quality of life rather than curing the illness. Palliative care teams help manage symptoms and provide emotional support. This care can be given at any stage of kidney disease, not just at the end of life.

renalTeam.title: Renal Team (Kidney Care Team)
renalTeam.definition: The group of healthcare professionals who look after you. This usually includes kidney doctors (nephrologists), specialist nurses, dietitians, counsellors, and others. They work together to give you the best care and support.

nephrologist.title: Nephrologist
nephrologist.definition: A doctor who specialises in kidney diseases. Your nephrologist leads your kidney care team and helps you make decisions about your treatment. They are experts in all types of kidney conditions and treatments.

anaemia.title: Anaemia
anaemia.definition: A condition where you have fewer red blood cells than normal, which can make you feel tired and short of breath. It is common in people with kidney disease because the kidneys make a hormone (erythropoietin) that helps make red blood cells. Treatment may include injections or iron supplements.

bloodPressure.title: Blood Pressure
bloodPressure.definition: The force of blood pushing against the walls of your arteries. High blood pressure is common in kidney disease and can make kidney damage worse. Controlling blood pressure with medicines and lifestyle changes is an important part of kidney care.

fluidBalance.title: Fluid Balance
fluidBalance.definition: The balance between how much fluid you take in and how much leaves your body. When kidneys are not working well, they cannot remove extra fluid, which can cause swelling and breathlessness. You may need to limit how much you drink.

potassium.title: Potassium
potassium.definition: A mineral found in many foods that helps your muscles and heart work properly. When kidneys are not working well, potassium can build up to dangerous levels in your blood. You may need to limit foods high in potassium like bananas, oranges, and potatoes.

phosphate.title: Phosphate
phosphate.definition: A mineral found in many foods that helps build strong bones. When kidneys are not working well, phosphate can build up in your blood and weaken your bones. You may need to take tablets called phosphate binders with meals and limit certain foods.

lifeGoals.title: Life Goals and Treatment Fit
lifeGoals.introduction: Everyone has different things that matter to them in life. By telling us about your goals, we can show you which kidney treatments might work best for the life you want to live.

howItWorks.title: How This Works
howItWorks.step1: Choose the life goals that matter most to you from the categories below
howItWorks.step2: We will show you how each treatment fits with your goals
howItWorks.step3: Use the results to start a conversation with your kidney team

lifeGoals.selectGoals: Select the goals that matter to you
lifeGoals.selectGoalsPrompt: Tick the goals that are important to you. You can choose as many as you like.
lifeGoals.noGoalsSelected: Select at least one goal to see results

work.title: Work and Career
work.description: Getting back to work, career plans, and managing your working hours

family.title: Family and Relationships
family.description: Looking after children, spending time with family, and being there for important moments

travel.title: Travel and Holidays
travel.description: Being free to travel, planning holidays, and being spontaneous

hobbies.title: Hobbies and Activities
hobbies.description: Sports, creative hobbies, social activities, and spending time outdoors

independence.title: Independence
independence.description: Looking after yourself, driving, living alone, and managing your home

religious.title: Religious and Cultural Needs
religious.description: Following dietary rules, prayer times, community events, and fasting

goals.returnToWork: Getting back to work or staying in work
goals.careerProgression: Progressing in my career or education
goals.childcare: Looking after my children or grandchildren
goals.familyTime: Spending quality time with my family
goals.milestones: Being there for family milestones and events
goals.travelFreedom: Being free to travel where I want
goals.holidayPlanning: Planning holidays without too much worry
goals.spontaneousTrips: Being able to take spontaneous trips
goals.sports: Playing sports or doing physical exercise
goals.creativeActivities: Doing creative hobbies like art, music, or crafts
goals.socialActivities: Going out with friends and socialising
goals.selfCare: Being able to look after myself day to day
goals.livingAlone: Living on my own if I want to
goals.managingHome: Managing my household and daily tasks
goals.dietaryNeeds: Following my cultural or religious diet
goals.prayerTimes: Being able to pray at the right times
goals.communityParticipation: Taking part in community or religious events
goals.fasting: Being able to fast when required

results.title: Your Treatment Compatibility
results.description: Based on your {{count}} selected goals, here is how each treatment fits with the life you want to live.
results.disclaimer: These scores are a guide based on your goals, not medical advice. Your kidney team will help you find the best treatment for your situation. Some treatments may not be suitable for everyone.
results.discussTitle: Things to Discuss with Your Team
results.discussIntro: Based on your goals, here are some questions you might want to ask your kidney team:
results.nextSteps: What Would You Like to Do Next?

discussion.work: How soon after starting treatment could I get back to work, and will I need time off for appointments?
discussion.family: How will treatment affect my energy levels for looking after my family, and can treatment times be flexible around family needs?
discussion.travel: What are the options for travelling while on treatment, and how much advance planning would I need?
discussion.hobbies: Are there any activities I would need to avoid, and how will my energy levels be for hobbies?
discussion.independence: How much help will I need day to day, and will I still be able to drive and live independently?
discussion.religious: Can treatment be scheduled around prayer times and religious events, and are there dietary considerations I should know about?
discussion.general: What support is available to help me maintain the lifestyle that matters to me?

returnToWork.transplant: After recovery, most transplant patients return to full-time work with few restrictions.
returnToWork.homeHd: You can schedule treatment around work, but sessions take several hours and you may feel tired after.
returnToWork.unitHd: Fixed session times 3 days a week can make full-time work challenging. Some employers offer flexible arrangements.
returnToWork.apd: Treatment happens overnight while you sleep, leaving your days free for work.
returnToWork.capd: You need to do exchanges during the day, which requires breaks from work. Many employers can accommodate this.
returnToWork.conservative: Your ability to work may change over time as kidney function declines.

careerProgression.transplant: A working transplant gives you the most freedom to pursue career goals with regular clinic visits.
careerProgression.homeHd: Career progression is possible but treatment hours need to be factored into your schedule.
careerProgression.unitHd: Fixed hospital appointments can limit availability for meetings, travel, and training.
careerProgression.apd: Overnight treatment leaves days free for work and career development.
careerProgression.capd: Daytime exchanges may require workplace adjustments but career progression is still possible.
careerProgression.conservative: Energy levels may reduce over time, which could affect work capacity.

flexibleHours.transplant: After recovery, you have full flexibility with only periodic clinic appointments.
flexibleHours.homeHd: You can choose when to do your treatment, giving reasonable flexibility.
flexibleHours.unitHd: Sessions are at fixed times set by the hospital, which limits flexibility.
flexibleHours.apd: Treatment runs overnight automatically, giving you full daytime flexibility.
flexibleHours.capd: Exchanges need to happen at regular intervals during the day, which can limit spontaneity.
flexibleHours.conservative: You have good flexibility as there is no treatment schedule, but energy may vary.

physicalJob.transplant: Most physical jobs are possible after recovery, though heavy lifting near the transplant site needs care.
physicalJob.homeHd: Physical work is possible on non-treatment days, but you may feel tired after sessions.
physicalJob.unitHd: Physical jobs can be difficult with treatment fatigue and fixed hospital times.
physicalJob.apd: Physical work is possible but you need to protect your catheter and avoid very heavy lifting.
physicalJob.capd: Heavy physical work can be challenging with a catheter in place.
physicalJob.conservative: Physical capacity may reduce gradually as kidney function declines.

childcare.transplant: After recovery, you can fully participate in childcare with good energy levels.
childcare.homeHd: Childcare is possible but treatment hours require another carer to be available.
childcare.unitHd: Being away from home for hospital sessions means you need childcare cover 3 days a week.
childcare.apd: Overnight treatment means you are free during the day for childcare.
childcare.capd: You can care for children between exchanges, but you need clean breaks for each one.
childcare.conservative: You can care for children but energy levels may decline over time.

familyTime.transplant: A working transplant gives you the most freedom for family time with good energy.
familyTime.homeHd: Treatment at home means family is nearby, but sessions take several hours.
familyTime.unitHd: Hospital visits take time away from family, typically 3 times a week plus travel.
familyTime.apd: Overnight treatment leaves your days and evenings free for family.
familyTime.capd: Exchanges take about 30 minutes each, but you are home and available between them.
familyTime.conservative: No treatment time away from family, but energy levels may reduce over time.

milestones.transplantLiving: A living donor transplant can be planned to fit around important events.
milestones.transplantDeceased: After transplant you are free to attend events, but waiting time is unpredictable.
milestones.homeHd: You can adjust treatment timing for special occasions with some planning.
milestones.unitHd: Attending events may require swapping hospital sessions, which needs advance planning.
milestones.apd: You can skip or adjust one night's treatment for special events after checking with your team.
milestones.capd: You need to continue exchanges but can plan them around events.
milestones.conservative: No treatment restrictions for events, but energy levels may limit participation.

intimacy.transplant: Relationships and intimacy generally improve after a successful transplant.
intimacy.homeHd: Intimacy is possible but body image and energy levels can be affected.
intimacy.unitHd: Fatigue and body image concerns may affect intimacy, but support is available.
intimacy.apd: The catheter may affect body image, but most couples adapt with time.
intimacy.capd: Similar to APD, the catheter can affect confidence but couples find ways to adapt.
intimacy.conservative: Intimacy is possible but may be affected by tiredness and changing health.

travelFreedom.transplant: You can travel freely with just your medications. Travel insurance is needed.
travelFreedom.homeHd: Travel requires arranging dialysis at your destination, which limits options.
travelFreedom.unitHd: You need to book holiday dialysis sessions at a unit near your destination well in advance.
travelFreedom.apd: You can travel with your machine and supplies, but need to organise delivery of fluids.
travelFreedom.capd: You can travel by arranging fluid delivery to your destination in advance.
travelFreedom.conservative: Travel is possible based on how you are feeling, with no equipment needed.

holidayPlanning.transplant: Holiday planning is straightforward with just medications and insurance to organise.
holidayPlanning.homeHd: Holidays need significant advance planning to arrange treatment at your destination.
holidayPlanning.unitHd: You need to book holiday dialysis weeks or months ahead, which limits choice.
holidayPlanning.apd: Holidays are possible with planning for machine and supply delivery.
holidayPlanning.capd: Holidays need advance planning for fluid delivery to your destination.
holidayPlanning.conservative: Holiday planning is flexible but depends on how well you are feeling.

spontaneousTrips.transplant: Spontaneous trips are easy with just your medications to bring along.
spontaneousTrips.homeHd: Last-minute trips are very difficult as treatment arrangements take time.
spontaneousTrips.unitHd: Spontaneous travel is very challenging due to fixed hospital session requirements.
spontaneousTrips.apd: Spontaneous trips are difficult as you need your machine and supply delivery arranged.
spontaneousTrips.capd: Spur-of-the-moment trips are hard as you need fluid supplies wherever you go.
spontaneousTrips.conservative: Short spontaneous trips are possible depending on your energy levels.

sports.transplant: Most sports are possible after recovery. Contact sports may need protective gear.
sports.homeHd: Exercise is encouraged on non-treatment days. You may feel less energetic after sessions.
sports.unitHd: Sports are possible but energy levels and fixed schedules can be limiting.
sports.apd: Many sports are possible but you need to protect the catheter from impact.
sports.capd: Swimming and contact sports may be restricted due to the catheter. Walking and light exercise are fine.
sports.conservative: Light exercise is beneficial but stamina may decrease over time.

creativeActivities.transplant: Creative hobbies are fully possible with good energy levels.
creativeActivities.homeHd: You can do creative activities during treatment or between sessions.
creativeActivities.unitHd: Many units allow reading, crafts, or laptop use during sessions.
creativeActivities.apd: Full freedom for creative hobbies during the day.
creativeActivities.capd: Creative activities are fully possible between exchanges.
creativeActivities.conservative: Creative hobbies can continue as long as you have the energy.

socialActivities.transplant: Social life can return to normal after recovery.
socialActivities.homeHd: Social activities need to be planned around treatment hours.
socialActivities.unitHd: Fixed hospital sessions can limit evening and weekend social plans.
socialActivities.apd: Days and early evenings are free for socialising. Late nights need planning.
socialActivities.capd: You can socialise between exchanges, but need to plan around them.
socialActivities.conservative: Social activities are possible but may be limited by energy levels.

gardeningOutdoors.transplant: Gardening is fine but wear gloves and sun protection due to immunosuppression.
gardeningOutdoors.homeHd: Gardening and outdoor activities are possible on non-treatment days.
gardeningOutdoors.unitHd: Outdoor hobbies are possible but limited by treatment schedule and energy.
gardeningOutdoors.apd: Days are free for gardening and outdoor activities.
gardeningOutdoors.capd: Gardening is possible between exchanges. Keep the catheter site protected.
gardeningOutdoors.conservative: Outdoor activities can continue as energy allows.

selfCare.transplant: Full self-care independence is normal after transplant recovery.
selfCare.homeHd: You manage your own treatment at home after training, building independence.
selfCare.unitHd: Others provide your treatment, but daily self-care remains independent.
selfCare.apd: You manage the machine setup yourself. Daily self-care is independent.
selfCare.capd: You do your own exchanges, maintaining good independence.
selfCare.conservative: Self-care may need more support as kidney function declines over time.

driving.transplant: Driving can resume a few weeks after surgery once you are comfortable.
driving.homeHd: Driving is possible, though you should avoid it immediately after treatment if tired.
driving.unitHd: Driving to and from the unit is possible but some people feel tired after sessions.
driving.apd: Driving is not affected by overnight treatment.
driving.capd: Driving is generally fine between exchanges.
driving.conservative: Driving depends on your overall fitness and any symptoms you have.

livingAlone.transplant: Living alone is fully possible with a working transplant.
livingAlone.homeHd: Home HD usually requires a care partner to be present during treatment.
livingAlone.unitHd: Living alone is manageable as treatment happens at the hospital.
livingAlone.apd: Many people on APD live alone successfully after training.
livingAlone.capd: Living alone is possible with good training and support.
livingAlone.conservative: Living alone may become more difficult as health changes over time.

managingHome.transplant: Full household management is possible after recovery.
managingHome.homeHd: Managing a home is possible but treatment equipment needs space and time.
managingHome.unitHd: Household tasks may build up on treatment days when you are away.
managingHome.apd: Daytime freedom allows normal household management.
managingHome.capd: Household tasks can be managed between exchanges throughout the day.
managingHome.conservative: Household management may need more help as energy levels change.

dietaryNeeds.transplant: Fewer dietary restrictions than dialysis, though some foods may interact with medications.
dietaryNeeds.homeHd: Dietary restrictions on potassium, phosphate, and fluid may conflict with some cultural diets.
dietaryNeeds.unitHd: Same dietary restrictions as home HD. Your dietitian can help adapt cultural recipes.
dietaryNeeds.apd: PD has some dietary flexibility but fluid and phosphate limits still apply.
dietaryNeeds.capd: Similar to APD, some dietary restrictions apply but they may be less strict than HD.
dietaryNeeds.conservative: Dietary guidelines apply but may be less strict. Cultural needs can often be accommodated.

prayerTimes.transplant: No treatment schedule means full freedom to pray at required times.
prayerTimes.homeHd: You can schedule treatment sessions to avoid prayer times.
prayerTimes.unitHd: Hospital session times may conflict with prayer schedules. Speak to your team about options.
prayerTimes.apd: Treatment happens overnight so prayer times during the day are unaffected.
prayerTimes.capd: Exchanges can usually be timed to avoid conflicting with prayer times.
prayerTimes.conservative: No treatment appointments to work around prayer schedules.

communityParticipation.transplant: Full participation in community and religious events is possible.
communityParticipation.homeHd: Community events can be attended by planning treatment around them.
communityParticipation.unitHd: Fixed hospital sessions may clash with regular community events.
communityParticipation.apd: Days and evenings are free for community participation.
communityParticipation.capd: Community events are possible with planning exchanges around them.
communityParticipation.conservative: Participation is possible based on energy levels and wellbeing.

fasting.transplant: Fasting may be possible with medical advice, as medications need to be taken.
fasting.homeHd: Fasting during dialysis is very challenging due to fluid needs. Medical advice is essential.
fasting.unitHd: Fasting on treatment days is generally not recommended without medical guidance.
fasting.apd: Fasting may be possible on non-treatment nights with careful medical guidance.
fasting.capd: Fasting with PD exchanges is challenging. Discuss modified fasting with your team.
fasting.conservative: Fasting may be possible depending on your health, with medical guidance.

page.title: What others in similar situations chose
page.introduction: Understanding what others have chosen can help you feel less alone in your decision. These are real statistics from UK kidney patients.

disclaimer.title: Important: These are general statistics
disclaimer.body: The statistics shown here are based on data from thousands of patients across the UK. They show general patterns and trends, not predictions about your individual situation.
disclaimer.advice: Your kidney team will help you understand what these numbers mean for you personally. Many individual factors affect outcomes that statistics cannot capture.
disclaimer.inline: These are population-level statistics. Your individual situation and outcomes may differ.

chart.title: Treatment choices
chart.overallBasis: Based on all UK kidney patients on treatment
chart.note: These percentages show the current treatment choices of all patients receiving kidney replacement therapy in the UK. New patients starting treatment may have a different pattern.

basis.overall: Based on all UK kidney patients receiving treatment
basis.ageGroup: Based on people in your age group
basis.ethnicity: Based on people with a similar ethnic background
basis.disease: Based on people with a similar kidney condition
basis.diabetes: Based on people with diabetes-related kidney disease

ethnicityTransplant.title: Transplant rates and ethnicity
ethnicityTransplant.lowerRate: People from your ethnic background currently have somewhat lower transplant rates. This may be due to biological matching factors or access differences. Your kidney team can discuss transplant suitability with you regardless of background.
ethnicityTransplant.higherRate: People from your ethnic background have similar or higher transplant rates compared to the overall population.

diabetes.title: Diabetes and kidney treatment
diabetes.description: Diabetes is the most common cause of kidney failure in the UK. Treatment choices for people with diabetes are roughly evenly split between transplant and haemodialysis, with about 1 in 10 choosing peritoneal dialysis.

livingDonor.title: Living donor available
livingDonor.description: Having a potential living donor is a significant advantage. Living donor transplants generally have better long-term outcomes and can often be planned ahead, reducing or eliminating time on the waiting list.

ageConservative.title: Conservative management
ageConservative.description: For older patients with other health conditions, conservative management (supportive care without dialysis) is a valid choice that some patients prefer. Your kidney team can discuss whether this might be appropriate for your situation.

ageTransplant.title: Transplant in younger patients
ageTransplant.description: Younger patients tend to benefit most from transplantation, with the highest success rates and longest graft survival. About 3 in 4 younger kidney patients currently have a transplant.

qol.title: Quality of life comparison
qol.subtitle: How patients rate their quality of life on different treatments
qol.transplant: Transplant recipients generally report the highest quality of life, with the most freedom from treatment routines.
qol.peritonealDialysis: Peritoneal dialysis patients often report good autonomy and flexibility, as treatment can be done at home.
qol.haemodialysis: Haemodialysis patients may experience more treatment burden due to regular hospital or clinic visits.
qol.conservative: Conservative management patients avoid dialysis burden but may have increasing symptoms over time.
qol.burdenNote: Treatment burden reflects the time and effort required for treatment. A lower score means less burden on daily life.
qol.scoreNote: Scores are based on patient-reported outcomes from published UK studies. Higher scores indicate better quality of life. Individual experiences may vary significantly.

waitingList.title: Transplant waiting list
waitingList.subtitle: Key facts about the kidney transplant waiting list in England
waitingList.onList: Patients currently on the kidney waiting list
waitingList.livingDonorAvailable: You may have a living donor
waitingList.livingDonorAdvantage: Living donor transplants generally have better outcomes and shorter waiting times. About 30% of kidney transplants in the UK are from living donors.
waitingList.note: Wait times vary by blood group, tissue type, and other matching factors. Your kidney team can give you more specific information about likely waiting times in your area.

survival.title: Survival information
survival.subtitle: Contains sensitive statistical information
survival.warning: The following information contains survival statistics. These are population averages and vary greatly based on age, overall health, and many other individual factors. They should not be interpreted as predictions about your personal outlook.
survival.transplantContext: Transplant offers the best long-term survival rates. Living donor transplants have slightly better outcomes than deceased donor transplants.
survival.hdContext: Survival on haemodialysis varies significantly by age and other health conditions. Many patients do well for many years on dialysis.
survival.pdContext: Peritoneal dialysis survival is broadly similar to haemodialysis. The best choice depends on individual lifestyle and medical factors.
survival.conservativeContext: Conservative management is typically chosen by older patients with significant other health conditions. It focuses on quality of life and symptom management.
survival.note: Survival rates have improved significantly over recent decades and continue to improve with advances in treatment. Your kidney team can discuss what these figures mean in the context of your individual health.

team.title: Discuss with your kidney team
team.description: These statistics provide general context, but your kidney team knows your individual situation best. They can help you understand what these numbers mean for you and answer any questions you have.
team.point1: Ask about your individual risk factors and expected outcomes
team.point2: Discuss which treatments are realistic options for you
team.point3: Explore how your lifestyle and preferences fit with each option

sources.title: Data sources
sources.disclaimer: Statistics are derived from published reports and may be subject to rounding. They represent population-level data and should not be used for individual clinical decisions without professional guidance.

ukrr.name: UK Renal Registry (UKRR)
ukrr.description: Annual report providing comprehensive data on kidney replacement therapy across the UK.

nhsbt.name: NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT)
nhsbt.description: Activity reports on organ donation and transplantation in the UK.

nice.name: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE)
nice.description: Clinical guidelines for the management of chronic kidney disease.
